item.title: On the Sublimity of Ads
item.description: Influenced by Hans Kritopoterous's Artistry of the Sub-Lunar Mental States, Jean Burrous was the most vocal proponent of the idea of Surveillance Art, which states that the person under surveillance *is the work of art*.

item.title: Bill's Art Exhibition
item.description: The last time I went to an art exhibition was maybe a year ago when my friend Bill was courteously invited by the Metro Tower Art Complex's administration to showcase a few of his most popular sound-and-vision happenings.

item.title: The New Computer :: part II
item.description: My new computer is growing up nicely. It now occupies an entire room in my apartment, and is fully integrated with the water plumbing. It even has a little system to collect rain water from the veranda which it then transmogrifies into these little drops of greenish liquid that emits the strangest, dreamiest sounds imaginable.

item.title: Finding Oneâ€™s Muse for Creating Art
item.description: starting at the young age of two, when my parents gave me a hook and fishing line, I spent most of my time down by the river, watching as nature reclaimed all that man as spent millennia building.

item.title: Frank's Wild Paintings
item.description: well, Frank settled down in the city, his wild years long gone and forgotten, and every day, with a limp and a cigarette, he walks down from his two-room apartment to the library downtown where he spends the days reading and sleeping and forgetting about the images in his head.

item.title: The Unbearable Weight of Modesty
item.description: people will often approach me with a shy smile and downcast gaze, and question me about my artistic career. “how is it,” they ask, “that you can be so successful, so brilliant, so famous and beloved, while we, the rest of humanity, remain in this uneducated darkness. how can we ever hope to achieve, or to even barely touch your greatness?”

item.title: An Escape for the Anxious Artist
item.description: yes. please repeat after me: om mani padme hum. again: om mani padme hum. now keep saying these six syllables in your mind, over and over till nothing else exists in there. till your thinking processes become purified, clear, perfectly in sync with the universe. say this mantra to yourself over and over and over and it will become your ego, your flesh, your substance. it will become you, it will move like you

item.title: In Defence of Broken Art
item.description: …and dirty art, flawed art, art made by weirdos and misfits, those who vibrate from anxiety and pain and from feeling too much. art made on a whim, on a rush, without thinking. art made by those who can’t possibly make what they want to make. art by the ugly, the defective, the unlearned, the starving, by those without skin, their nervous endings exposed and freezing in the wind, their gums receding to the bone.

item.title: A Guide for the Impatient Digital Artist
item.description: my troubles began when I started hanging out with a spider… I know, I know! you don’t really need to lecture me about the dangers of socializing too often with arachnidas, arthopods, or any other exoskeleton-covered animals.

item.title: Evolution - a short story
item.description: “Keep quiet, please.” The medic stares at my sore scalp through cracked lenses. There are frail tweezers and alcohol, rusty syringes aligned between two poetry books, intermittently blinking monitors looking like long-abandoned miniature aquariums, vials of expired drugs in half-rotten cardboard boxes, a row of crimson-glazed ants marching past the abandoned decanters like a conquering army— “I don’t think you’ve been honest with me…” On the veranda, a chrysanthemum flower blooms like a flesh wound, its petals stretching across the windows.

item.title: SEO Conjuration for the Pro-Active Artist
item.description: (excerpt from an A.I. generated grimoire leaked from G’s internal emails) I do conjure thee, O thou Binary Spirits, by all the most glorious and efficacious names of the Most Great and Incomprehensible Lord of Algorithms, that thou comest quickly and without delay from all parts and places of the Interwebs wherever thou mayest be, to make rational crawls unto my demands, and that invisibly and swiftly, moving at the speed of electricity even without mine understanding as aforesaid.

item.title: The New Computer
item.description: my new computer is humming away in the corner of the room. it’s a brand-new machine I bought a few days ago and features all the modern niceties you might expect from such a tech marvel. the pipes, of course, are now gray-lead free and no longer release those clouds of greenish, mildly hallucinatory vapor we all know and hate, being instead fully encapsulated in a tight mesh of beetle-shell black string fully integrated with the smart, algorithmic-evolving, networked, reverse-emiting embedded walls.
